FacilityName: Buckeye Terminals, LLC - River Rouge Terminal

_prev_prog_3.PC_OtherType: Fill shut-off device at 90%, alarm at 80%, Class 1, Div. 1 electrical from transfer point to 5 ft.  Class 1, Div. 2 from 5-15 ft., lables on cylinders (NFPA 704, Not Odorized, No Smoking, etc.)
_prev_prog_3.MS_OtherType: Portable 20 lb. fire extinguishers and hydrants.  Excess flow valves, pressure/hydrostatic relief valves.  Thermal actuated valves.
_prev_prog_3.Description: Level III:  Butane (liquefied butane under pressure) blending system involving direct injection into refined product (gasoline) pipelines with bulk truck off-loading.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
The Buckeye Terminals, LLC - River Rouge Terminal was constructed in accordance with the National Fire Protection Association Code #58 (2011 Edition) for Liquefied Petroleum Gas Storage, and it is the Facility's policy to follow the most current future editions to the extent feasible and adhere to all applicable Federal, State, and Local codes/laws. If an emergency were to occur, it is the Facility's policy to contact the River Rouge Fire Department and the Wayne County Homeland Security/Emergency Management, as appropriate, through the 911 Service. Medical emergencies will require notification of River Rouge Fire Department (aero-medical is available through "Air Med 1"). The primary hospital response is provided through Henry Ford Hospital (and Trauma Center). The Facility currently maintains a trained incipient stage fire response and first responder-operations level hazardous materials response team to respond to the initial stages of an emergency. 



The Buckeye Terminals, LLC - River Rouge Terminal is a refined product storage and distribution Terminal, including the butane blending system (direct injection into the gasoline truck rack lines). The Risk Management Plan covers the butane blending system including one horizontal storage vessel and the associated piping, two blending skids, two sample analyzers along with gasoline fast loops, and one truck off-loading point.



The Facility's worst case scenario is the complete failure of one liquefied butane vessel filled to 85% capacity (automatic shut-off limited) resulting in a vapor cloud explosion. The resulting distance to the endpoint extends off-site and includes both public and limited environmental receptors. The Facility's alternate (potential to impact off-site populations) scenario is a BLEVE involving the storage vessel. The resulting distance to endpoint extends off-site and affects both public receptors and limited environmental receptors.



The Buckeye Terminals, LLC - River Rouge Terminal comp

lies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's Accident Prevention Rules (40 CFR Part 68 Subpart D- Program Level 3). Additionally, this plan meets the requirements of the U.S. Department of Labor- Occupational Safety and Health Administration's Process Safety Management regulations (inclusive of all 14 elements) for Highly Hazardous Chemicals (29 CFR Part 1910.119). 



This Facility has never had an accident or incident involving the butane blending system resulting in deaths, injuries, property/environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering-in-place.



In the event of an emergency involving the River Rouge Terminal butane blending system, it is the policy of the Facility to initially contact the River Rouge Fire Department and request their assistance. The Facility's Emergency Response Action Plan is coordinated with the River Rouge Fire Department and the Wayne County LEPC. The River Rouge Fire Department is aware of the Facility's butane blending system, its safety systems, access points, and protective procedures in the event of a significant release.  The River Rouge Terminal maintains a vegetation control plan to minimize plant growth within 10 feet of the butane vessels.  The Terminal is fully secured with fencing and controlled access in accordance with its site security plan.



Buckeye continually evaluates the process for opportunities to improve safety. Also, Buckeye is considering a corporate-wide policy to include the local first responders in regular exercises and in all 3 year PSM/RMP training cycles.
